posts.name: Jimmy Burke
posts.cooked: We are trying to set up the encoders for the shooter on our robot, and we connected the two motors together and connected them both into one digit input on our electronics board. However, the encoder needs 2 digital inputs, and we only have the one. Is there a method that takes just one digit input for the encoder or should we unsolder the wires?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm not sure I understand your electrical layout right now.  What encoder model are you using?  How are they wired?  What motor controllers are you using?

The reason quadrature encoders require 2 DI ports is because they use 2 channels offset by 90 degrees so that you can tell direction.  A single channel would only be able to identify rate, not direction.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Your shooter is only going in one direction, correct?  You can use the Tachometer class.  Your resolution will be cut in half compared to reading the full quadrature signal, but it‚Äôll still work.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: A DIO encoder needs two DIO ports. The encoder should be wired to the DIO as follows: +5V to +5V Ground to Ground A (on the encoder) to Signal on the DIO you plugged power into B to Signal on the second DIO

posts.name: Jimmy Burke
posts.cooked: If by one direction you mean only up and down then yes, but the shooter only moves up and down. The motors that are being connected to the encoder are spliced together and sharing a single motor controller and are used to aim the shooter.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Oh, this motor is being used to aim the shooter?  You will need a full quadrature signal for that, or else an analog signal (like a potentiometer).

posts.name: Jimmy Burke
posts.cooked: I have checked and they are plugged in, in that way.

posts.name: Jimmy Burke
posts.cooked: is it still the same if it is two motors spliced together and is connected to one talon srx motor controller which the encoder is connected to. And by quadrature signal do you mean the one with the 5v, ground, and A and B signals?
Then you should be fine. Just pass the two DIO ports into the Encoder when your creating it in code. Maybe I don‚Äôt understand the problem?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: If the encoder is connected to the TalonSRX, and your Talon is on the CAN bus (it would really not make much sense for it not to be if the encoder is plugged into it), then there should be no DIO ports involved.

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
two motors spliced together and is connected to one talon srx motor

Just to confirm, you are using one of the motors that you are allowed to put two on one controller per R504, correct?

one talon srx motor controller which the encoder is connected to.

Oh so the encoder is connected to the Talon‚Äôs Data Port? So what exactly is the issue here?

Is it that you have an encoder on each of the two motors?  If so, you can probably get away with only hooking up one (to the Talon SRX) and not the other provided the OUTPUTs of the two motors are mechanically tied together such that they can‚Äôt physically spin at different rates (ie. into a 2 motor gearbox like the Toughbox Mini). Of course the preference in such a situation is usually to have the encoder on the output of the gearbox not on the individual motors.

posts.name: Jimmy Burke
posts.cooked: The issue is that when we hook it up through the data port then it said we needed two digital inputs.

posts.name: Jimmy Burke
posts.cooked: Like an error came up.

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
Where did this error appear? In your code in VS Code? In the RIOLog/DriverStation Output? Somewhere else? If so, could you copy/paste the entire error for us?

The issue is likely that you are either physically wiring the encoder wrong, or your programming is incorrect. I can‚Äôt troubleshoot the programming without seeing your code, preferably posted to a code repository hosting service like https://github.com/ .

For physical wiring, double check that you have your Quadrature Encoder‚Äôs A and B connected to the correct pins of the Talon SRX Data Port:

link_counts.title: GitHub: Where the world builds software ¬∑ GitHub

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked: OR are you saying your encoder only HAS one digital input, in which case, I‚Äôd like to know more about what encoder you are using, because non-quadrature encoders usually only give you a speed/velocity, and not also a direction, which if this is for aiming your shooter and you need bi-directional control you would need.

posts.cooked: I have no idea what I‚Äôm looking at here? It looks like the Talons are connected into some kind of board or something?

posts.name: Jimmy Burke
posts.cooked: The talons are connected to the power board and that part that has green tape around it is the encoder plugged into the motor controller. The second picture is of the two motors that are connected to that talon, since they are spliced together. Their goal is to be able to aim that white plastic thing in the middle which is our shooter.
